LOS ALAMOS WILD FIRE FORCES EVACUATION OF 25,000 PEOPLE FROM THEIR
HOMES

  (SUBS 7th and 8th grafs with 5 new grafs on status of lab; ADDS new
last graf of 1st take with number of houses destroyed; ADDS Clinton
quotes in 2nd and 3rd grafs of 2nd take; CORRECTS ``Monument'' to
``Park Service'' in penultimate graf before optional trim in 2nd
take)  
 By JAMES STERNGOLD   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   LOS ALAMOS, N.M. _ Fed by winds gusting at up to 50 miles an
hour, a wild fire here resumed its path of devastation on Thursday,
forcing the evacuation of as many as 25,000 people and destroying
at least 150 homes, perhaps twice that number, but apparently not
causing serious damage at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, where
nuclear weapons are designed.

   As officials warned that there was still little chance of
bringing the blaze under control until the weather changed, a
growing chorus of local and national officials began to express
their anger at the National Park Service, which set what it had
hoped would be a controlled fire a week ago before high winds sent
it racing across heavily wooded canyons toward the populated areas.

   As reports circulated here that the National Weather Service had
warned before the fire was set that high winds were expected, the
Interior Department, which operates the park service, announced
late in the day that Roy Weaver, the superintendent of the
Bandelier National Monument, where the fire was set, was placed on
administrative leave pending an investigation.

   ``I believe someone is responsible,'' Sen. Pete Domenici,
R-N.M., said at a press conference here on Thursday morning. ``The
person in charge at the park service who authorized the burn is
most responsible.'' He added that he intended to ask for a federal
investigation of the plan.

   Although more than 18,000 acres have already burned and more
than 1,000 emergency and fire personnel have been brought in to try
and control the fire, there have been no injuries reported and the
hasty evacuation of the huge number of people was described as
orderly.

   But Los Alamos presented a disconcerting tableau on Thursday,
during a reporter's visit to the blackened streets. Fire vehicles
rushed about, the skies dark with thick plumes of white smoke and
helicopters occasionally whirring overhead, carrying huge buckets
of water. Most neighborhoods presented an eerie checkerboard of
destruction, with houses seemingly selected at random for total
destruction alongside other homes left unscathed.

   Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, who flew in from a conference
in San Diego Thursday morning, said the Los Alamos National
Laboratory had suffered some fire damage but was secure. Energy
Department officials said the fire had passed over some concrete
and earth bunkers where conventional explosives are stored, causing
no damage. The officials said that at one point the fire had come
within 300 yards of a building where plutonium is stored but that
the building is heavily fortified and is safe. Though some nuclear
material is stored at the laboratory, there are no nuclear weapons
there.

   Richardson said there were no signs that any radiation had been
released.

   Of the 11,000 people who work at the laboratory, only security
guards and one dozen or two dozen workers in the emergency
operations center remain, said Kay Roybal, a spokeswoman for the
laboratory.

   Roybal would not speculate on how experiments might be affected
by the closing of the laboratory but said that scientists each year
must plan around a shutdown from Christmas through Jan. 1. ``I
think there are ways to handle most of that,'' she said. ``Whether
people had time to do that this time, I can't say.''

   Each day of the shutdown costs from $3.5 million to $5 million
in salaries.

   Initially, just the 11,000 or so residents of Los Alamos, a tidy
town high on a mesa at about 7,200 feet, had been evacuated. But
starting on Wednesday night and then throughout the day on Thursday
the residents of the nearby towns of White Rock and the Espanola
Valley, as well as Abiqui, were told to leave the area. Abiqui is
famous for having been the home of Georgia O'Keefe, the artist, for
many years and much of her work is still kept there.

   A local radio station took calls from people all day who
recounted having been given just minutes to clear out of their
homes. Many said they had had time to do little more than throw
some clothes into plastic garbage bags, grab their pets and
children and flee, with the smoke and flames visible nearby. One
man called in to ask if any of the authorities had information
about his two dogs; he had not had time to bring them in before he
departed in haste on Wednesday night.

   The streets of Los Alamos were a crazy quilt of random
destruction. The heat of the fires transformed many houses, cars,
utility poles and lawns into cinders. Typical was 49th Street in
the western part of the city, where the once tidy homes were razed
in twos and threes, while right alongside them other homes were
untouched, the grass still green.

   Viola Stowe, a resident of the city, who had been evacuated to a
shelter at a high school in Espanola, said she watched a house burn
on the television news on Wednesday night, and only when the camera
pulled back did she realize it was her own.

   ``You don't plan for these things,'' she said. ``You don't think
it'll happen to you.''

   City officials said it appeared that at least 150 houses had
been destroyed and that the number might go as high as 300.

   nn

   President Clinton has already declared the region a disaster
area, making it eligible for federal aid, and emergency officials
flew in on Thursday from Washington to both help control the fire
and to plan relief efforts.

   Thursday in Washington, when asked about the government's
liability for the fire, the president said, ``We have to look in to
see what the real facts are and what the responsibility of the
government is.

   ``Right now we should be focusing on doing everything we can to
minimize the damage of the fire and protect the lab assets, deal
with the human problems,'' Clinton said.

   The fire was burning to the north and to the northeast on
Thursday, away from populated areas. But firefighters were still
concerned, in part because the flames were spewing burning chunks
of wood thousands of feet in the air, where they were being blown
as far as a mile and starting new fires. Also, any shift in the
winds could push the fires toward homes and the nuclear lab, where
some buildings have already been singed.

   Kevin Purtymun, a Los Alamos police officer, said another
concern was that because the fires had left many houses and trees
standing, there was still plenty of fuel if the blaze roared across
the city again.

   ``Really, anything can happen now,'' said Mike Gowey, a Forest
Service firefighter. ``There are spot fires everywhere. This is
nowhere near under control.''

   The National Park Service defended the practice of setting
controlled fires, saying the fires are an essential means of
heading off devastating accidental fires in forests that have grown
overly dense because of fire suppression over the years.

   ``The purpose of a prescribed burn is to eliminate underbrush to
head off catastrophic fires,'' said Michael Gauldin, the chief
spokesman for the Interior Department. He said such burns were
conducted over millions of acres every year, by the Forest Service,
the Park Service and the Bureau of Land Management.

   The fire was intentionally set last Thursday as part of a
continuing effort by Bandelier National Monument to thin out some
of the dense growth that makes the pine forests in the region among
the most combustible in the country.

   Park Service officials say they weighed the factors that go into
such planning: the amount of wood and other tinder in the forest,
the moisture content of the fuels, the relative humidity and
temperature of the air, and the speed of the wind. Then they
plugged the data into a computer program and decided conditions
were auspicious for a safe and effective burn.

   ``The data and the spot weather forecasts met the fire
prescription,'' the Bandelier superintendent, Weaver, said in an
interview before his suspension was announced. ``It's not like
someone was just picking things out of the air.''

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   Weaver said the fire team had requested and received weather
updates throughout the day, as late as two hours before the flames
were ignited at 7:20 p.m. Thursday. Seeing no reason to call off
the plan, the crew set the fire. Then, he said, the winds whipped
up unexpectedly, and the flames began spreading toward Los Alamos.

   About seven hours before the fire was set, the National Weather
Service office in Albuquerque faxed a report, requested by
Bandelier, predicting that winds on the ridgetops would increase to
10 to 15 miles an hour that evening, gusting to 20 miles an hour
the next day. The report also said relative humidity would not
increase as much as it normally does in the evening, ranging
between 15 percent to as high as 30 percent after midnight. A more
normal nighttime reading is 50 to 60 percent.

   The weather report also predicted that a factor called the
Haines index, which measures the tendency of smoke and flames to
rise vertically, was at its maximum level _ 6 on a scale of 2 to 6.

   Dr. Wallace Covington, a professor at Northern Arizona
University's School of Forestry in Flagstaff, said that these
numbers, while not ideal, would not automatically rule out a burn.
If the ground is too wet and the air too still, he said, a burn
will not do its job. And while a high Haines index might mean
flames are more likely to leap into the tree tops, starting a
rapidly proliferating ``crown fire,'' the vertical motion also
helps keep smoke away from settlements.

   ``It's the devil and the deep blue sea,'' Covington said.

   Weaver said that his staff attempted a prescribed burn in the
same area in fall 1992, when the air was more humid and still. ``It
accomplished nothing,'' he said. ``We wasted our time and
resources. ``
